author: butta9417
content:
On MEV-Boost at merge: 

Currently many parties across the eco-system, from r/ethstaker to staking pools are gearing up for the merge and deciding whether to implement/guide users to use MEV-Boost.

While the small delay at the merge before MEV-Boost is activated is certainly helpful,  there is still a large risk to block production post-merge if much of the network activates MEV-Boost and there is a problem.

I am writing this to ask the EF (e.g. <@552133098075193354>) and CL teams to consider putting out guidance on whether they suggest  that users activate MEV-Boost prior to/at the merge, or if it would be better for the network to phase in MEV-Boost usage over time after the merge is complete and the MEV-Boost flow has had time to demonstrate its stability.  

Without any such guidance I fear that many users will assume that MEV-Boost has been tested/engineered to the same standards as the rest of the merge infrastructure, which I do not believe to be the case.

author: ajsutton
content: I'd say the key message is that people need to understand they are trusting the relay and should monitor to make sure it really is working properly. The automated fallback handles most cases but can't help with a relay that fails to reveal the payload after the block header is signed.  And you always to make sure the produced block really did pay you the tx fees it promised.

author: ajsutton
content: It's simple to verify.  You check that your fee recipient balance increased by the amount the builder promised it would after processing the block.  Whether they paid you for every cent of mev included isn't important - just that they paid what they offered.

author: ajsutton
content: In an ideal world if what is offered is less than what your local EL would have earned then you'd pick the block from your local EL but I don't think there's any support for that currently (the engine API doesn't currently include information how much the local block would earn the fee recipient)

author: ajsutton
content: I would expect that builders are paying as little to validators as possible. It's why you want to have multiple builders and then you pick the one that pays the most.

author: ajsutton
content: ie competition will force them to pay the validator more and keep less for themselves.

author: butta9417
content: While I do think MEV-Boost is unfortunate, I acknowledge it is the best/only fleshed out mitigation for the MEV issue.  I'm just concerned about the short-term reliability/performance of it surrounding its initial activation.  CL teams hands are tied by the risks to client diversity in terms of forcing a significant delay post-merge prior to activation.  Users and Pools, by contrast, have very little to lose by waiting ~24hrs or so to confirm successful block production before activating (and it seems like an easy win for reducing overall merge risk/complication).
